awd_titl_txt: Modulators of the Abscisic Acid Core Signaling Pathway
awd_abstract_narration:
Increases in the human population of the Earth, coupled with increased carbon emissions, are leading to changes in our global climate that threaten agriculture just as our collective demands grow. Climate change is manifest as severe weather events ranging from warming and drought to major storms and flooding in different regions. The combination of severe drought during growing seasons and excessive moisture during cereal grain maturation can lead to many billions of dollars in annual yield losses worldwide. A better understanding of the genetic mechanisms controlling plant stress tolerance and productivity could help us to create or breed plants that could better withstand unfavorable climate events. The hormone abscisic acid (ABA) is a key regulator of stress signaling. Within the last seven years a "core ABA signaling pathway" has emerged that mechanistically links many ABA signaling components that were previously identified genetically. This proposal addresses the function of a group of proteins that interact directly with multiple central components of this core pathway, possibly functioning as signaling hubs. Understanding the interactions controlling ABA responses could be instrumental for ensuring the world's future food security. 

The central components of the ABA core signaling pathway include four families of proteins: the PYL/PYR/RCAR family of ABA receptors, the clade A family of protein phosphatase (PP)2Cs, the Snf-Related Kinase (SnRK)2 family,and the ABI5/ABF/AREB clade of ABA response element binding basic leucine zipper (bZIP) class transcription factors. An additional family, the ABI Five binding Protein (AFP)s, interact directly with the bZIPs, PP2Cs and SnRK2s, and also show interactions with chromatin modifiers. This project will address the mechanisms and implications of these interactions by determining 1) whether AFPs act as transcriptional repressors of ABA response element (ABRE)-containing genes by sequestering bZIPs at low ABA concentrations; (2) whether AFPs interact with TPL-like co-repressor(s) or other chromatin modifying protein(s) to alter histone acetylation and activity of genes regulated by bZIPs; and 3) whether AFP function and localization is regulated by changes in phosphorylation mediated by PP2Cs and SnRK2s or other kinases. The proposed experiments will test how the AFPs contribute to a feedback system that permits plants to resume growth when developmentally or stress-induced ABA levels decline. In addition, they will address the biochemical function(s) of a family still annotated only as proteins of unknown function.

por.por_cntn:
The hormone abscisic acid (ABA) is a key regulator of seed maturation, germination control and responses to environmental stresses including drought and salinity, all of which have major impacts on crop productivity. The goal of this project was to understand how a class of proteins of unknown biochemical function, the ABI-Five-binding Proteins (AFPs), regulate response to ABA. We sought to determine the mechanism(s) by which these mysterious proteins contribute to a feedback system that permits plants to resume growth when developmentally or stress-induced ABA levels decline.

The central components of the ABA core signaling pathway include four families of at least nine proteins each: the PYL/PYR/RCAR family of ABA receptors, the clade A family of protein phosphatase (PP)2Cs, the Snf-Related Kinase (SnRK)2 family, and the ABI5/ABF/AREB clade of ABA response element binding basic leucine zipper (bZIP) class transcription factors. We had previously found that the AFPs interacted directly with several of the transcription factors, kinases and phosphatases in this signaling pathway. Phosphorylation can alter protein conformations, and consequently interactions and localization within cells. We found that the AFPs were directly modified by the kinases and phosphatases that alter phosphorylation, and identified specific amino acids that were being modified. To test the significance of these modifications, we created mutations that would either prevent or mimic phosphorylation and reintroduced the mutant genes into plants. This identified a subset of phosphorylated amino acids that were critical for AFP protein stability and consequently function. Furthermore, confocal microscopic studies showed that the phosphorylation state of these proteins affected whether they were more likely to be dispersed into small foci or uniformly distributed within nuclei, consistent with undergoing phase transitions.

We used a genetic approach to test the frequently cited hypothesis that the AFPs were adaptors for enzymes that would target the ABA responsive transcription factors for destruction and found it to be false. In the course of these experiments, we generated seeds that had the unusual combination of good seed viability despite extreme ABA resistance. Proteomic analysis of these seeds identified a subset of stress-induced proteins that are highly correlated with tolerance of dehydrating stresses, which is likely to be of general interest and of practical significance for characterizing quality of seed batches.

Gene expression is affected by chromatin conformation as well as availability of transcription factors to regulate specific genes. We also tested the hypothesis that these proteins would recruit chromatin-modifying proteins to ABA-regulated genes, resulting in reduced expression of those genes. We found that most of the effects leading to inhibition of ABA-regulated genes were likely to be indirect. Our transcriptome analysis produced the surprising result that although both ABA and an inhibitor of the chromatin-modifying proteins inhibited germination, the expression profiles of seeds incubated with these regulators were vastly different. Further analysis of this data is in progress, and should allow us to identify a subset of genes and processes strongly correlated with blocking germination.

Another aspect of the project was identifying additional proteins that were part of this signaling network. We found that the AFPs act as signaling hubs, interacting with all components of the ABA core signaling pathway including some receptors, scaffolding proteins that specifically interact with phosphorylated proteins, and also with proteins that are central to signaling by other hormones.

Broader impacts directly related to this project were primarily developing human resources by training 8 undergraduates (5 women, 3 men) over the course of the project, including two women from traditionally underrepresented groups. Three of the women subsequently entered graduate programs, two students went to medical school, one was hired by a biotech company, one is currently applying to graduate programs, and the most recent student has not yet graduated. In addition, identification of proteins highly correlated with desiccation tolerance and genes tightly associated with germination control can provide a basis for agricultural applications.
